summary: Payment programs that tie reimbursement to provider quality or outcomes are widely implemented, but the evidence on their impact is mixed — showing modest gains in process metrics and limited improvements in health outcomes.

articles.title: Pay for Performance in Healthcare: A Systematic Review of the Literature
articles.summary: A 2017 systematic review found that P4P can improve process measures modestly, particularly in outpatient settings, but has no consistent effect on patient health outcomes.

articles.title: The Effects of Pay-for-Performance Programs on Health, Health Care Use, and Processes of Care: A Systematic Review
articles.summary: This systematic review of 69 studies finds low-strength evidence that P4P programs may improve process-of-care outcomes, particularly in ambulatory settings with poor baseline performance. However, it shows no consistent effect on intermediate or patient health outcomes.
